SENT.plain: Benign nocturnal alternating hemiplegia (BNAH) of childhood is distinct from the classic form of malignant alternating hemiplegia of childhood [1]
It is characterized by hemiplegic attacks occurring exclusively during sleep [2]
It can be misdiagnosed as migraine, nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy, benign rolandic epilepsy, Panayiotopoulos syndrome, or sleep-related movement disorder [1-4]
Only nine patients have been described to date, with typically, a normal development [1,5-7]

In order to insist about the benignity of the affection, we report two cases: a new three-year-old boy suffering from BNAH and a patient already published to show positive evolution at fourteen years of age
BNAH is a rare disorder but may be underdiagnosed
Making an early diagnosis can help to describe to the parents the good prognosis without treatment
